summary: Igor Nosenko was a Soviet KGB officer who defected to the United States in 1964. His defection and subsequent interrogation by the CIA became highly controversial. The documents indicate that Nosenko's interrogation was a sensitive matter, discussed at high levels, including a briefing to President Johnson. The CIA was concerned with verifying Nosenko's claims, including whether he had been in the United States under an alias. Checks were also conducted with Nosenko regarding the Wallenberg case and PD DIPPERS. The documents also mention the opening date of the Nosenko NBR material. The handling of Nosenko's case and the information he provided were subjects of internal review and external inquiries, including those by the HSCA.
significance: Nosenko's significance in the JFK assassination context stems from his potential knowledge of the KGB's involvement, or lack thereof, in the assassination. His defection and the CIA's assessment of his credibility were crucial in determining whether Lee Harvey Oswald had any connections to the Soviet Union. The controversy surrounding Nosenko's defection and the information he provided has continued to fuel debate and investigation into the JFK assassination.
